verses.text: Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God, and \add be\add* more ready to hear, than to give the sacrifice of fools: for they consider not that \add they\add* do evil.
Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be hasty to utter \add any\add* thing before God: for God \add is\add* in heaven, and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few.
For a dream cometh through the multitude of business; and a fool’s voice \add is known\add* by multitude of words.
When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it; for \add he hath\add* no pleasure in fools: pay that which thou hast vowed.
Better \add is it\add* that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest vow and not pay.
Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin; neither say thou before the angel, that it \add was\add* an error: wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thine hands?
For in the multitude of dreams and many words \add there are\add* also \add divers\add* vanities: but fear thou God.

If thou seest the oppression of the poor, and violent perverting of judgment and justice in a province, marvel not at the matter: for \add he that is\add* higher than the highest regardeth; and \add there be\add* higher than they.
Moreover the profit of the earth \add is\add* for all: the king \add himself\add* is served by the field.
He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied \add with\add* silver; nor he that loveth abundance \add with\add* increase: this \add is\add* also vanity.
When goods increase, they are increased that eat them: and what good \add is there\add* to the owners thereof, saving the beholding \add of them\add* with their eyes?
The sleep of a labouring \add man is\add* sweet, whether he eat little or much: but the abundance of the rich will not suffer him to sleep.
There is a sore evil \add which\add* I have seen under the sun, \add namely\add*, riches kept for the owners thereof to their hurt.
But those riches perish by evil travail: and he begetteth a son, and \add there is\add* nothing in his hand.
As he came forth of his mother’s womb, naked shall he return to go as he came, and shall take nothing of his labour, which he may carry away in his hand.
And this also \add is\add* a sore evil, \add that\add* in all points as he came, so shall he go: and what profit hath he that hath laboured for the wind?
All his days also he eateth in darkness, and \add he hath\add* much sorrow and wrath with his sickness.

Behold \add that\add* which I have seen: \add it is\add* good and comely \add for one\add* to eat and to drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labour that he taketh under the sun all the days of his life, which God giveth him: for it \add is\add* his portion.
Every man also to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eat thereof, and to take his portion, and to rejoice in his labour; this \add is\add* the gift of God.
For he shall not much remember the days of his life; because God answereth \add him\add* in the joy of his heart.
